Posts.Title: Zero Cancer - An end to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: As the others have mentioned, being diagnosed with Stage4 prostate cancer with lots of Gleason 8-10 and very high to astronomical PSA might not be as horrid as it obviously sounds. The guys with S4 and lots of metastatic tumors are in many places are now getting ADT+Chemo as the 1st line of treatment. In some areas guys with low volume metastatic PC might get radiation treatments along with ADT or in other areas they may get ADT/CAB/TAB (sorry I can spell out what the letters stand for). There are a few DR's who make use of C11-PET scans and play "wack-a-mole" with radiation therapy and have some success (DR Kwon @ the Mayo Clinic comes to mind). Dr. "Snuffy" Meyers has had success prescribing a few drugs "off label" in the fight against PC with much success. While every case is different and some men's PC responds better than others (or not at all) to treatment there are cases where Stage4 PC can be managed like a "chronic illness" for longer than what might of been possible even just 10yrs ago. I was just reflecting that it was nearly 2yrs ago today that I was diagnosed with Stage4 Metastatic Prostate Cancer. I'm still around. g.

Posts.Title: Stage IV Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kathy77 He ruled out surgery for various reasons which I understand but I'm left wondering why wait for the radiotherapy??? I think Dad will receive it but the consultant wants to wait and see how he reacts to the hormones. Because of the odds of the cancer coming back if there actually IS a positive lymph node, many DR's and medical centers won't offer surgery or radiation. However if after some months on treatment the suspect lymph node is scanned again and it is unaffected by the treatment, it is likely not cancerous and they can move forward with a curative treatment of Radiotherapy. Hence the delay.

Posts.Title: Stage IV Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I debated on posting on this as the forum is generally upbeat and positive. The story here is not. I felt that I needed to write somewhere about it as it hits close to home. The Prostate Cancer Forum seemed to be the best place. I've known Dennis since the late 1980's. Always a "fun loving" and "party animal" the guy loved hunting, fishing, "chasing tail" and seemingly never grew up. A year ago August he was in a traffic accident and during his 2 week stay at the hospital they tossed all sorts of tests at him in attempts to get a "complete picture" of what might be ailing him. Since he was ~60yo at the time one of those tests was a PSA test. The result of the PSA test was rather shocking to everyone - over 1200. While he had no UTS or other indication of PC when he was well enough they gave him the standard barrage of tests that most of us go through. The good news was his Gleason score was low, biopsy/scans showed only partial involvement of one lobe of his prostate however contrasting that the scans showed PC from the top of his head to his feet plus bone and liver invasion. I talked to him at length about it last March/April and while he'd recently took early retirement (and switched to SSD/Medicare) he was upbeat that he had "slow growing kind" and the planned ADT+Chemo would keep him enjoying the outdoors for years to come. While I personally questioned his upbeat prognosis (based on my own research) I kept my unprofessional opinions to myself and kept in mind that every case is somewhat different and who really knows how things might pan out. While modern life has moved much communication with old time friends to texts, email and Facebook, actual phone calls are somewhat rare these days. Nobody wants to get "the call". A dozen or more of us got it, dropped whatever we were doing and collected at a hospital. It seems that Dennis had gotten the Flu and since the PC was in his bone marrow he had little or no immune system to fight it. They had already given him 1/2 dozen units of blood and at the point of us getting "the call" the staff was merely helping him hold on until his daughter arrived from out of state to see him for the last time. Its debatable if he knew of any of our being there. His whole family was there at his side and many/most of his friends had stopped by to see him that day. Dennis passed away Saturday 1hr after his daughters arrival. May he RIP.

Posts.Title: On a not so lighter note....

Posts.Content: Thanks for the kind words everyone, this hits close to home as he was 1 of 4 people (including myself) I've known that over the last 5yrs got diagnosed with PC, 50% are no longer with us. This case surely flies in the face of the industry attempts to move away from early detection - had he been tested 20 or even 10yrs ago he still may be with us. I believe that it also highlights that "slow growing" cancer can be just as deadly as the more aggressive types. Since his actual prostate only had "spots" on one lobe, he had no UTS or other troubling symptoms until the cancer reached enough bone to cause discomfort and in the end pain. The PC may of been growing in him for decades. While very few cases (arguably less than 5% or less than 1% depending on your statistic source) are initially diagnosed at S4 and even less with distant mets+bone+organ involvement, my guess is that "Flu" will be listed as the cause of death, further muddling the PC survival statistics. IMHO: if anyone is planing a colonoscopy, they ought to get a DRA and PSA test at the same time. Why test for ONE type of cancer while ignoring another type that is much more common?

Posts.Title: Generic Viagra in Mexico

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon Wow, those meds are expensive, how often do you get the shot and for how long? The health care system I'm signed up with has a pharmacy and a nurses station (along with lots of other departments). While my urologist prescribed them, the Lupron shots are given to me via the nurses station. There are a number of different shots available which have different frequencies of getting them. Personally I'm on the 4month version. For me the cost is covered completely by my current health care plan. I could not imagine having to bear the costs of these shots "out of pocket". As far as duration of getting the shots I'm understanding it is dependent on what the shots are being used for. Some patients may have them prescribed for 1yr or less while others (such as myself) may get them pretty much forever or until they stop having benefit (and/or stop working).

Posts.Title: Update on SRT + ADT

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Last week had my third uPSA since completing ART and was thrilled (no, shocked) that all three came back as 0.0 ... Per another thread that was Quest so I wonder if that was actually "<0.02"?? ... But I won't be looking this gift horse in the mouth! So now we move to six month testing, but since my testosterone is only nine (yes, that's 009) my Uro said that it's unlikely much will have changed by then. And with this being my 999th post on this forum, what could be more fitting than rolling the odometer over to three zeroes in a row? Hopefully as the Lupron wears off I may regain some semblance of brain power once again. But I'm pretty sure that my little head (you know, the second head that controls us guys) is probably down for the count. But where one door closes, another opens. Last October after completing RT I had an MRI that was inconclusive after an ENT had found a mass in my throat. One thing led to another and I had nasopharyngeal surgery in April, after which he said he "couldn't get to it" (this just keeps getting better). So as mentioned in another forum I started prednisone yesterday and am having a CT tomorrow. Not sure where this may lead but it's fairly safe to assume it's NOT cancer. I do appreciate the well wishes I've had from everyone. At least I won't be worrying about PCa for a long while. Congratulations!!! I hope to be there sometime myself.
